conclusion: The radar emits a pulse lasting 1 microsecond and the interval between two emissions is 100 microseconds.
The display shows three peaks: a, b, and c.
Given ab = bc, the time intervals between these peaks are equal.
Each interval is 50 microseconds because the total interval between emissions is 100 microseconds and ab = bc.
The time between a and b (or b and c) represents the round-trip time for the radar wave to travel to the obstacle and back, which is 50 microseconds.
One-way time to the obstacle is 25 microseconds, which is half of the round-trip time.
Convert 25 microseconds to seconds: 25 microseconds = 25 x 10^-6 seconds.
Speed of light, c = 3.0 x 10^8 m/s.
Distance = speed x time, which is 3.0 x 10^8 m/s x 25 x 10^-6 seconds.
The distance between the obstacle and the radar is 7500 meters.
